Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 12:43PM - edited Aug 26, 2011 12:44PM by imbell Check out My T Cells are off to Boot Camp on these boards. A very promising treatment. Here is a CBC news article. A breakthrough therapy to modify patients' T-cells into potent tumor-killing agents has helped three leukemia sufferers stay cancer-free for a year, US researchers said Wednesday. The findings are the first to show how gene transfer therapy can create specialized T-cells, which guard the body from infection, that attack cancerous tumors in advanced cases of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). The technique helped patients who had little hope of survival fend off their cancer and stay in remission, said the research published simultaneously in the New England Journal of Medicine and Science Translational Medicine. Further studies are needed, but the advances offer hope to people who suffer from similar cancer types such as ovarian, lung, myeloma and melanoma Those further studies are in progress. Ask your doctors.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2011 06:39AM imbell wrote: Long Term Disability & Social Security Disability    Can you collect on both your Long Term Disability policy and collect Social Security Disability claims?  For purposes of SSDI calculations, your LTD benefits are not evidence of "substantial activity" and thus do not offset your SSDI.  However, many LTD policies do provide for an offset - that is, your LTD benefits paid by the private insurer will be reduced by whatever Social Security payment you receive.    Often, you will find that LTD carriers require claimants to apply for Social Security since Social Security benefits can reduce  the amount of money that the LTD carrier must pay over the  course of a claimant's lifetime. In addition, the Medicaid and  Medicare benefits that accrue to Social Security beneficiaries  can reduce the health insurance costs to a LTD carrier.    In a best case situation, your LTD carrier can help your Social Security lawyer work your Social Security case as the LTD adjustor may have a complete medical file.  Other times LTD carriers offer no assistance.    You need to find out what your LTD policy says about Social Security.  If you are receiving LTD benefits while you are waiting for a Social Security decision, and you eventually win your Social Security claim, your LTD provider may require you to pay back all of your lump sum to the LTD carrier as part of a reimbursement clause.    Some LTD carriers will pick up the cost of your Social Security legal fees, while others will not.  Here, too, you need to find out your carrier's policies as early as you can so you can make an informed decision regarding legal counsel.    If you are receiving or applying for long term disability, make sure to advise your Social Security lawyer WHO ARE THE FORUM POLICE. I THINK THEY SHOULD BE OUTED

Posts.Content: imbell wrote: I am beginning to question my treatment.  Diagnosed in 2006 with stage IIIb 5/5 nodes. After the usual treatment I went on Armidex. Have been getting Pamidronate shots since last December. Took Xeloda for 4 courses but there was progression on the pet scan done two weeks ago, so onc took me off.  I am only on the Pamidronate. Have more tests coming up.  Saw the radiation doc last week. He questioned why I wasn't on hormonal therapy even if the Arimidex did not work. I feel that my treatment has been iffy. Decisions are only made when I go to the office. Am I panicking unnecessarily. What is the treatment for a triple positive. Should I pursue the radiation route. Won't cure it but would cut back on the pain and discomfort or am I taking a chance by not going on Abraxane immediately. P.S. Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 11:18PM - edited Mar 25, 2011 11:37PM by imbell Check  out the Low Income Energy Network (depends on which city you live in). and the Ontario Association of Food Banks. Have you taken advantage of disability tax credits. I am retired but I have a disability certificate at Revenue Canada that saves me about $900 in taxes and is transferable to spouse. Some doctors can't figure it out but my family doc had cancer and one of the criteria is that you take daily medicine to stay alive. My drug was Arimidex. Taxes can be reassessed for up to 4 years. Coupons are a waste around here but store brands are a better deal. Safeway, Superstore and Sobeys all have them. Check out the flyers on Flyerland.ca but you have to know your prices. We are retired. I couldn't pry any money out of my life insurance company but our house appreciated in value considerably. We have a credit line based on the house mortgage.  Doubt either one of us will make it five years and we both have life insurance. Our heat and electricity are on a monthly budget. We couldn't pay our winter bill if we weren't. Manitoba has a life saving drug program which is a good thing because as retirees our Blue Cross drug benefit is $450 per year. If anyone needs to keep warm, check out electric mattress pads. Better than a blanket because they don't get as hot and it doesn't fry your shoulders while your feet freeze over. When I am on chemo I get cold chills plus achy joints from the side effects. It has been a life saver One more thing we had a new toilet put in and new showerhead (the new kind that save water). Can't believe our water bill was halved and we haven't noticed any difference. The toilet is only a 6 litre but flushes very hard (from Rona) and the shower head has an aerator so you feel like you are getting the same amount of water as the old one. I forgot Dollarama for kitchen iutensils, towels, tools, birthday decorations, kids and adult gloves, food items, etc. Most of their stuff is now $1.25 but that is still less than most stores.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 01:04PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:48AM by imbell The reality is that Canadian oncs dont even want to fill out a prescription. A good surgeon will see her every 3 months and then every six months. her backup for drugs, etc. is her GP. The oncologist should also be seeing her every 3 months. If she requires assistance at home, there is Home Care and Meals on Wheels will deliver food (fresh or frozen for a very nominal amount. She can contact the local cancer society for transportation to her appointments and if she needs further treatment. Cancercare MB provides your first bra and prosthesis. You can also get wigs at the cancer society. They all work along the same lines.Anyone can ask for reconstruction. I*t is an 8 hour procedure but they don't take any muscle these days only fat. She may even be able to do an implant if she doesn't have radiation.  There is a website called Guidelines in Oncology. Once she gets her pathology report and it does take a while, you can follow her treatment and see if she is getting the care she requires. Depending on her report it could be chemo and radiation followed by hormone therapy. Every test and scan takes time burt have patience because this cancer did not come up overnight. It takes time to grow. You miight want fo post hour province for more help.
